page.title: 01Carry Moor, Barrow Hill &
page.content: The block has been intensively farmed with dairy cattle and sheep since time immemorial. The Yeovil/Castle Cary railway line crosses the block roughly N/S and th River Cary, which rises in Castle Cary but is now little more than a ditch,crosses the block roughly E/W. On the E side of the block is a ridge containing Barrow Hill and Cockhill, from which the ground slopes westward down to the valley of the River Cary, an area known as Cary Moor, which is flat and low-lying. There are two ancient villages in the block, Galhampton and North Barrow, and signs of a deserted medieval village between them. Castle Cary borders the block to the N and the A359 runs part of the way along the ridge. The diarist Parson Woodford preached at North Barrow for a while, and his nephew Colonel William
